_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Note:  This facility was previously part of the DuPont Sabine River Works Plant.  On April 30, 2004, the facility assets were purchased by INV Nylon Chemicals Americas, LLC and DuPont was the landlord. DOW Chemical Company purchased DuPont in 2019; therefore, INV Nylon Chemicals Americas, LLC - Orange Site is a tenant of DOW's Performance Materials NA, Inc.



1.0  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

INV Nylon Chemicals Americas, LLC - Orange Site (INV Orange Site) management is committed to preventing process-related incidents that might affect plant personnel, off-site communities, the environment, or result in significant property or business loss. We firmly believe that we can operate our processes without inuring or endangering employees or the community.

Our policy for process safety management is to comply with INV Nylon Chemicals Americas, LLC Process Safety Management Standard, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR Part 68). The INV Orange Site's Risk Management Program contains the management systems and controls for our diversified processes so that potential hazards are identified, understood, and controlled. It is the responsibility of each individual employee to know, understand, and comply with the site PSM policy and systems.

Management ensures that employees are involved in all aspects of the Risk Management reviews, auditing, and development of procedures and training programs.



1.1 THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site is located approximately 2 miles South of the city of Orange on FM 1006. The site is located on 72 acres and the facility is secured by a chain-link fence, video cameras, controlled entry, and a 24 hour security force. DuPont as the land owner is responsible for sec

urity and emergency response for the site.

The site consists of manufacturing processes to produce Nylon Intermediates [hexamethylenediamine (HMD) and Adiponitrile (ADN)]. The Adipic Acid unit was decommissioned during the 4th quarter 2015 and is now limited to storage facilities for anhydrous ammonia. In the production of HMD and ADN, the following regulated substances are used as raw materials, intermediates, or by-products:

- Ammonia (anhydrous)

- Ammonia (conc. 20% or greater)

- Hydrocyanic Acid (HCN)

- 1,3-Butadiene

A barge dock was commissioned on August 28, 2015 for supplying 1,3-Butadiene to the ADN production unit or sending 1,3-Butadiene offsite. The barge dock is manned whenever a barge with 1,3-Butadiene is at the barge dock. The barge dock has controlled entry, is secured by a chain-link fence, and the area is under video camera surveillance from the ADN unit control room. The U.S. Coast Guard conducts periodic inspections of the facility. The most recent inspection was conducted on September 11, 2019 by the U.S. Coast Guard. 

In September 2018, INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site Nylon C eliminated chlorine 1-ton containers used for water treatment from the ADN process, which eliminated a significant risk to the community and demonstrated INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site's commitment to Environmental Stewardship. 



1.2 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE CHEMICAL- SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The regulated substances and corresponding processes at INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site are also regulated under the OSHA PSM standard. The PSM and RMP programs share common accidental release prevention requirements and corresponding program elements. In complying with the PSM standard, INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site has taken the necessary steps to comply with the applicable accidental release prevention requirements of the RMP regulation.

INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site's Accidental Re

lease Prevention Program incorporates safety into process and equipment designs:

- A documented process technology system covers hazards of materials, equipment design basis, and process design basis,

- Extensive accident prevention and mitigation systems are strategically located,

- Applicable codes and standards are met or exceeded,

- Materials of construction are chosen to provide mechanical integrity,

- Quality Assurance ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications and proper assembly.

INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site maintains the regulated processes with safety in mind:

- Maintenance personnel are qualified and trained,

- Contractors are trained and qualified,

- A work permit system controls hazards,

- All non-replacements-in-kind (non-RIK) changes are documented through site Management of Change (MOC) procedure.

INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site incorporates safety into regulated process operations:

- Operators are trained and job qualified,

- Technical resources are available and utilized as required,

- Operators follow approved procedures.

INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site audits the prevention program and its implementation:

- Routine safety inspections are conducted,

- Corporate, independent and governmental audits and reviews are conducted,

- Process Hazards Analyses are conducted,

- Safety equipment are set up on a periodic inspection frequency to ensure ongoing mechanical integrity,

- Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to starting up any new or modified equipment,

- Quality assurance of critical equipment ensures fabrication in accordance with design specifications,

- Incidents are investigated and actions taken to prevent recurrence.



1.3 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

In the last 5 years, the INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site has not experienced a release of a regulated substance that resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, or the need for evacuation

or sheltering in place.  However, on October 10, 2012, the site had a release of a regulated substance that resulted in two onsite injuries.  The release was attributed to an upstream isolation valve that was not fully closed when a downstream flange was removed.  Contributing factors to the event include implementation of procedures for energy control and establishment of perimeters during line break activities.



1.4 Emergency Response Program

Plant personnel are trained and equipped to respond to any releases of the regulated chemicals. The INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site has a service level agreement with the landlord, DOW's Performance Materials NA, Inc.

. Key program provisions include:

- Plant personnel receive emergency response training,

- Plant emergency responders, including the INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site and DuPont personnel, are trained,

- Emergency response plans are current,

- Plant participates in emergency drills,

- Critiques are held on drills and actual events,

- Plant is a member of the Orange County Local Emergency Planning Committee.

If a major release occurs, the following actions are taken:

- Emergency alarm is sounded,

- Community emergency responders are notified as appropriate,

- Emergency communicated to DuPont, which activates the Plant Emergency Operating Center,

- Plant Incident Commander and emergency squad respond.



1.5 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Through process hazard analyses, the INV Nylon Chemicals Americas - Orange Site has developed actions and implementation schedules for improving the safety of its regulated processes. The list of actions and implementation schedule are presented in PHA reports maintained in facility files.
